newsitem.title: HONG KONG: BT Fund Managers sees HK's Hang Seng at 15,500 pts.
newsitem.headline: BT Fund Managers sees HK's Hang Seng at 15,500 pts.

text.p: BT Fund Managers Ltd said on Monday it had set a year-end target for Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index of 15,500 points but positive liquidity flow could push the blue chip index to 16,000 or beyond.
"Short-term we might get close to 15,000," BT Fund Managers vice president Dio Wong told a news conference.
The Hang Seng Index shot into new record territory on Monday, surging 242.96 points, or 1.70 percent, to an all-time closing high of 14,574.64.
The index hit an intra-day record high of 14,581.35.
Wong said earnings growth of close to 20 percent this year, a healthy property market, stable interest rates, and continued smooth economic growth in China should underpin share price rises.
Even if the U.S. Federal Reserve did decide to raise interest rates later in the year, "the downside in Hong Kong is not going to be too large," said Wong.

He said red chips should continue to dominate the market but investors should be cautious, particularly since Chinese authorities were likely to introduce measures on asset injections over coming months.

"It is my belief that they are promulgating a set of rules at the moment...Some of these assets are being sold too cheaply," said Wong. "I would not be surprised if in the next two or three months we see a set of rules come out."

"Mature" red chips should continue to perform well, but he said there were some "developing" or "dark horse" categories whose market capitalisations were "ridiculously out of proportion to their assets and earnings". In the long run, the mania for red chips was not healthy, Wong added.
He said there was likely to be a period during the second half of the year when the overall market would stagnate. But he said prices should then rally into the year end.

"Based on a conducive liquidity environment, we think that banking and particularly property stocks can continue to perform well for the rest of the year," said Wong. "Our view is that we will see another small uptick in the property market of around 10 percent from the recent bottom."
